title: Quality Control & Continuous Improvement
description: Apply Cost of Quality framework, prevention vs detection economics, and continuous improvement methodologies (Kaizen, Six Sigma).
objectives: Distinguish Prevention (defect avoidance) from Detection (inspection) and their cost trade-offs
Apply Cost of Quality (CoQ): Conformance (prevention + appraisal) vs Nonconformance (failure costs)
Use root cause analysis (5 Whys, Fishbone) to prevent recurring defects
Select appropriate methodology: Kaizen (incremental) vs Six Sigma (breakthrough)
Understand PDCA Cycle (Plan-Do-Check-Act) for continuous improvement

screens.headline: $12K/Month in Rework Costs. Casey: 'Inspect More!' Jordan: 'Prevent Defects, Don't Just Catch Them.'

dialogue.text: Inspect everything! That's how we catch defects!

counterpoint.text: Inspection tells you WHAT failed. Prevention stops failures from happening. We're spending $12K fixing defects we could've prevented for $3K.

screens.learningHook: Apply Cost of Quality framework, choose prevention over detection, use root cause analysis to stop recurring defects.

screens.title: Quality Improvement Decisions
screens.instructions: Choose prevention strategies, calculate cost of quality, apply root cause analysis, and select improvement methodologies.

scenarios.title: Stage 1: Prevention vs Detection Trade-off
description: Portion inconsistency defect rate: 8% (40 defective meals/day)
Jordan: 'Invest in equipment upgrade + training ($4K one-time + $1K/month)'

options.text: Jordan's prevention plan ($4K upfront + $1K/month, reduces defects 8% → 2%)

feedback.correct: Prevention ($4K + $1K/month) reduces defect rate 8% → 2%, saving $6K/month in rework. Payback in 1 month. Prevention is investment, detection is expense.
feedback.incorrect: Inspection only CATCHES defects, doesn't prevent them. Jordan's prevention plan reduces defect rate at source, $5K/month net savings after 1 month payback.

questions.question: Total CoQ = $23K/month. Which cost should Alex reduce FIRST?

options.text: Reduce internal failure ($10K) through process improvement
Reduce external failure ($5K) by improving customer service

feedback.correct: Internal failure ($10K) is largest nonconformance cost—target THIS with process improvement. Reducing prevention/appraisal without fixing root causes shifts costs to external failures.
feedback.incorrect: Cost of Nonconformance ($15K = 65% of CoQ) is the problem. Internal failure ($10K) is largest—fix this through process improvement. Prevention is INVESTMENT, not expense.

scenarios.title: Stage 3: Root Cause Analysis - 5 Whys
description: Defect: Wrong ingredient labels on 15% of meals
5 Whys revealed: Broken barcode scanner → manual entry → typos → wrong labels
Root cause: Broken scanner ($300 replacement) forces manual entry

options.text: Replace barcode scanner ($300), eliminate manual entry
Accept 15% defect rate, refund affected customers

feedback.correct: Root cause analysis (5 Whys) identifies SYSTEMIC problem (broken scanner). Fixing root cause ($300) PREVENTS 15% of defects, far cheaper than ongoing inspection ($2K/month).
feedback.incorrect: Inspection finds defects. Process improvement prevents them. The 5 Whys revealed the broken scanner is the root cause. Fix the scanner ($300), not the symptoms.

scenarios.title: Stage 4: Kaizen vs Six Sigma Selection
description: Problem A: Kitchen staff waste 15 min/day searching for utensils (2% productivity loss, team collaborative)
Problem B: Meal contamination rate 2,000 DPMO (target <100 DPMO, food safety risk)

questions.question: Match each problem to the appropriate methodology:

feedback.correct: Kaizen for daily waste (small, team-driven improvement). Six Sigma for contamination (critical safety defect, data-driven breakthrough). Match methodology to problem severity.
feedback.incorrect: Kaizen = continuous incremental improvements (daily inefficiencies). Six Sigma = data-driven breakthrough (critical defects, safety issues). Right tool for right problem.

content.strategy: Increase prevention (reduces failure costs more than investment). Reduce nonconformance (highest ROI).

content.rule: $1 invested in PREVENTION saves $10 in DETECTION and $100 in CORRECTION

fiveWhys.method: Ask 'Why?' 5 times to reach root cause
fiveWhys.example: Wrong labels → Manual entry → Broken scanner (root cause)

correct.text: Prevention ($4K investment) saves $6K/month in rework. Casey's inspection plan ($6K/month) never stops. Prevention is investment, detection is expense.
You correctly identified internal failure ($10K) as the largest cost to target. Invest in prevention to reduce nonconformance—that's where the ROI is.
5 Whys revealed the broken scanner. $300 fix prevents 15% defects. Root cause analysis prevents recurrence, inspection just finds it repeatedly.

screens.title: Vancouver Expansion Quality Plan
screens.context: Vancouver location has 3 quality issues after 2 months. Apply frameworks.

questions.question: 45 complaints/month. Top causes: Late delivery (25), Wrong order (12), Missing items (8). Which tool to prioritize fixes?
CoQ: Prevention $2K, Appraisal $6K, Internal failure $15K, External failure $8K. Which to reduce first?
Food temperature violations 3x/week. Current response: Retrain staff each time. Better approach?

options.text: Root cause analysis (5 Whys) to find systemic cause

screens.title: Quality Control & Continuous Improvement Mastery
screens.summary: Prevention is more cost-effective than detection. Cost of Quality: Invest in conformance to reduce nonconformance. Use root cause analysis for recurring defects. Match methodology to problem severity.
takeaways: Prevention ($1) vs Detection ($10) vs Correction ($100) economics
CoQ: Conformance (prevention + appraisal) vs Nonconformance (failure costs)
PDCA Cycle: Plan-Do-Check-Act for continuous improvement
Kaizen (incremental) vs Six Sigma (breakthrough)—match to problem
Root cause analysis: 5 Whys, Fishbone prevent recurring defects

artifacts.title: Cost of Quality Dashboard
artifacts.description: CoQ breakdown by category with improvement targets

characterClosing.text: We stopped spending $12K/month catching defects. Now we invest $3K preventing them. Prevention is investment. Detection is expense. Root cause analysis stops recurring problems.
